text: An essential role for NF-kappaB in human <extra_id_0> CD34 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) bone marrow cell survival .

The transcription factor , NF-kappaB , is important for T-cell activation , B-cell maturation , and human immunodeficiency virus transcription and plays a role in alternatively mediating and protecting against apoptosis in a variety of cell types .
However , a role for NF-kappaB in human <extra_id_0> CD34 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) bone marrow cells has not been described .

We provide evidence here that virtually all human <extra_id_0> CD34 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) bone marrow cells express NF-kappaB that can be activated by exposure to phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate and a variety of cytokines , eg , <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> interleukin-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: In addition , we demonstrate that NF-kappaB may be required for human <extra_id_0> CD34 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( + ) bone marrow cell clonogenic function and survival .

These results offer insight into a new role for NF-kappaB in maintaining survival and function in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells and suggest that proposed strategies involving inhibition of NF-kappaB activation as an adjunct to cancer chemotherapy should be approached with caution .
